Some say this hat helps you see in the dark. But it’s the ears that have us wondering…
Is that cow winking? Mais oui! She’s on your gorgeous head after all.
Show your stripes, and unleash the tiger on you.
You may be afraid of a lot of things, but wearing a chicken on your head? Not one of them.
You wouldn’t smile if you were endangered. Why should your hat?
Get the happiest feet around with Just Clownin’ multi-color clown shoes. These puppies are so impossibly comfy and roomy, your feet will grin from toe to toe.

Dress codes can be so confusing these days; formal, casual, semi-formal. This ensemble takes the guess work out of the equation. A button up shirt for dressing up and a cardigan for dressing down. Perfect!

An anonymous Sim once wrote, "O Hunk in a Cableknit Sweater, thou couldst not ever look better, than ye do… in a sweater." Bring those stirring words to life with this fashionable yet comfortable cableknit. We provide the sweater, you provide the hunk!
Ode to a Hunk in a Cableknit Sweater
The Shnoogle Up Hoodie is made from unicorn stallion hair. As they gallop around, engaging in combat, hair from their mane falls off and is collected for this unique hoodie. Oh also, just kidding.
On an adventurous jungle expedition, Dr. Salvanawana dressed in this jacket. It was durable, breathable, and last but not least, looked academically sporty! Indeed!

It's unfair to ask Bohemians to conform to mainstream society's ideals or fashion, but that doesn't mean we can’t befriend them or include them in our lives! This untucked vest should make them feel nice and comfortable because Bohemians feel naked without their vests.
The "I Guess" Tshirt is a no-brainer. It's a great option for Sims who want to wear clothes. Show the world how much you care or don't care with this loose fitting plain Tshirt.
This long-sleeved t-shirt is the rare cousin of the domestic short-sleeved t-shirt. By imitating its mating call, we were able to capture, domesticate and offer them in stores near you.
Admire the world through star-spangled glasses and marvel at how the world admires you.
The choice is yours: look festive in this oversized sombrero, or get along with others. You can’t do both in this hat. Which will win, your desire to meet people or your love of fun fashion?
A clown just isn’t a clown without a cheery little hat. Cut to fit even the largest head, with a secret compartment for hiding those perfect clown accessories, or just an extra snack.
Seriously, would you want to look Death in the face?
Don’t forget the hottest part of your Hot Diggity Dog suit! This stylish cap completes your look. Extra padding protects your head, in case someone tries to bite it.
Get that contagious smile you have always dreamed of. Happy Clown Facepaint is guaranteed to bring a smile to your face.
It may seem backwards, but studies have shown that sad clowns actually have more fun. It’s true. Everyone who sees sad clowns wants to cheer them up.
Can this Sim use the toilet standing?
This Sim will be able to:
Decorative spandrel with an angular geometric pattern for maximum eye appeal.
Wooden spandrel with an unfinished look to match your rustic interior.
This spandrel adds flair to your modest home without blowing your budget.
Decorative end caps make this spandrel resemble a tiny shelf.
Click to learn more about Styled Rooms.
Save Lot and Save Room are both ways in which you can save your creations for future use or to upload to the Gallery to share with other players.

Open the Save to Gallery menu and choose Save Lot in order to save your lot to My Library in the Gallery.\n\nAdd a lot name, description, and set the bed and bath count for your lot, then click on the Save Lot to My Library button to add it to the Gallery. This does not share it for others to view.
To share your lot for other players to view, click on the Share Lot to the Gallery button.\n\nAfter your lot has been shared, you can add and remove comments, and share your lot to Facebook.

Click to open the Save to Gallery menu and choose Save Room if you just want to save a single room, rather than your entire lot.\n\nNote: You will need to select the room you want to save before choosing this option.
Saved Rooms can be found in the Gallery menu under the My Library tab, as well as in the Rooms and Walls build catalog sort by choosing the Saved Rooms sort.

Use the Gallery to manage your saved Lots and Rooms by selecting the My Library tab, and clicking on your saved Lots and Rooms.\n\nFrom here, you can Share and un-Share your Rooms and Lots, Delete them from My Library, or Bring your Room or Lot into Build Mode to play with once again!
To share your Room for other Sims players to view, click on the Share Room to the Gallery button.\n\nAfter your Room has been shared, you can add and remove comments, and share your lot to Facebook.

Once you get going in Build, you will want to familiarize yourself with the various tools that are available to make customizing your home easier. Eyedropper, Sledgehammer, Design Tool, Move House, Select, and Bulldoze Lot… to name a few.\n\nSo dig in, and start building!
Use the Day/Night indicator to change the lighting in Build Mode in order to view your lot under different lighting conditions. The lighting does not persist when you exit Build Mode.
Basements can be placed as functional rooms below terrain level. In Build Mode, the basement tool can be found under Walls and Empty Rooms.
Basements can be placed up to four levels deep. Floors and ceilings can also be removed. In order for Sims to access basements, make sure to place some stairs!
Basements can be placed at ground level by using the Basement tool, or by moving the camera below-ground and placing rooms as normal.
Basements have a ton of new possibilities! Create underground labyrinths, or underground laboratories that are surrounded by pools.
Since basements are set below terrain, you cannot place windows or doors along the outer walls of the basement. Exterior walls also cannot be deleted.
Players can also choose to only show Community items. These objects are not required to be in venues, but are generic Venue items.
Of course - if you want to just see EVERYTHING - you can do that as well.
In Build Mode, players can easily sort items needed for Venues using Venue Sorting. Under Objects by Function, the default drop down displays all objects that satisfy the specified venue type.

Portions of the lot can be positioned outside the lot boundary. Anything outside the lot boundary is highlighted yellow and will be not be placed. Objects removed from outside placement will be stored in the Household Inventory.
The "Move Whole Lot" tool allows players to move and rotate the entire contents of a lot. This tool is helpful for lots placed from the Gallery as well as moving houses along any landscape.

The Move Lot tool can be found at the top tool bar under Move Lot and House.\n\nWhen the tool is selected, everything on the lot is grouped together and selected. A context menu provides options to pickup, rotate, and confirm placement.

This lesson will provide a quick overview of the features available in Build Mode! To learn more, select any lesson from this Lessons panel. Or, enter Build Mode and just start clicking around to see what happens.
To get started click on the Build Mode button in the upper right.\n\nProTip: You can also use F2 to jump directly to the Objects by Room catalog, or F3 to get into the Build catalog.

Start in the Rooms and Walls sort to begin building your home by plopping down fully furnished rooms from the Styled Rooms sub-sort. Or craft your own rooms by clicking on the Empty Rooms and Walls sub-sort.

Use the Build catalog to add doors, windows, roofs, floors, adjust the foundation, or add architectural flourishes like spandrels, roof attachments, trims, and friezes.\n\nOr change the patterns of the roof, floor, and walls; add a fence, gate, stairs, columns, outdoor décor and a fountain, or just paint the terrain. Go nuts!

To begin furnishing your home choose between the Objects by Room catalog, where you can imagine the décor of your home room by room. Or the Objects by Function catalog, when you would rather search for a specific functional need.

Can't find what you seek? Try Search. Just type what you are looking for and hit enter (or choose from the suggested items that pop up as you type).\n\nFilters can help to narrow down your search to a specific color or style.
Build Mode has several tools to help you build your perfect home.\n\nThe toolbar can be found in Build Mode along the top of the screen.
The Select tool is used to select objects and architecture found on your lot.\n\nWhile using any other tool, hitting [Esc] will always return to the Select tool.

The Eyedropper tool is used to copy the properties of a placed object or pattern, as well as some architectural elements (such as fences and spandrels).\n\nClicking on what you want to copy will attach a copy onto the cursor, as well as open to the home location of the copied item in the catalog.

Choose the Sledgehammer tool to delete and destroy.

Click on an object to delete it. Or click and drag to remove a group of similar items (all items to be deleted will highlight yellow).

Note: Bulldoze Lot is found in the Lot Info panel and is used to completely empty a lot. A warning, Bulldoze Lot can't be undone.

The Design Tool can be used to quickly change the color choice of objects that have already been placed.\n\nSelect the Design Tool. Click on an object and choose a new color from the swatch pop up. You will not be charged Simoleons for changing colors.

Click Undo to undo the last Build action. Click Redo to redo the last Build action.\n\nUndo and Redo are saved per build session. Once you exit Build Mode, you will not be able to Undo or Redo any changes from a previous Build session.

Make sure your Sims can get inside your creation and add a Door!\n\nProTip: In Live Mode, let the neighbors know where to go when they visit by clicking on any exterior door and choosing Set as Front Door.

To add a roof, click on Roofs and select one from the catalog. Once you click to place a roof, your floor view will change to make placement easier.\n\nProTip: A Room without a roof will be lit by the exterior lighting, and may not look the way you imagined it.
If you're holding an item on your cursor, you can rotate it by tapping the . or , keys.
Click to learn more about Doors.

Click on the Empty Rooms and Walls catalog or the Styled Rooms catalog to browse the different Rooms available.\n\nNote: You can create multiple stories by clicking on the Floor Up and Floor Down arrows in the upper right, and then placing a Room on the upper floors.

Click on a Room in the Styled Rooms catalog to get a larger view of the Room. From here you can buy individual objects or buy and place the whole Room to quickly add a new addition to your house.\n\nProTip: Double click on a Room in the catalog to allow for quick placement of the entire Room.

Doors can be sorted by height, or you can use the Show All sort and find the door height information in the hover tip for each door.\n\nNote: If the door you want doesn't fit on your walls, adjust the wall height at any time by clicking on any block and choose a wall height from the block gizmo.
You can also choose one of the suggested pop-ups that appear as you are typing.
The more expensive an object, the more likely it is to provide greater benefits to your Sims. Hover over an object in the catalog to see what type of benefits an object may provide.

Click on a placed Room to open up a context menu. Use the Move option to pick up and move your Room. Use Rotate Room to rotate your Room to the left and right. Or click and drag one of the wall arrows to resize the Room.\n\nProTip: Rotating can be destructive! Pick up your Room with the Move option and then use the keyboard shortcuts [<] and [>] to safely rotate.

Click on the Build catalog and then click on the Rooms and Walls sort found in the House Portrait.\n\nTo build any structure, you will need to start here. Here you can find Empty and Styled Rooms, Wall and Room tools, and any Rooms that you have saved.

Click on the Styled Rooms sort from within the Rooms and Walls catalog to browse the pre-made Rooms. Selecting the Room sort along the top switches the catalog of pre-made Rooms to the chosen Room type, such as BathRooms, Dining Rooms, or Kitchens.
Doors are found in the Build catalog by clicking on the Doors sort in the House Portrait.

Fridge? Baby? Contemporary? Rocket? Whatever you might be looking for, type it in the Search field, click on the Search button (or hit Enter) and see what you find.\n\nMisspelled something? Maybe it will still find what you are looking for or click the X button to start a new search.

Objects cost Simoleons. Open up the Objects by … catalogs and hover over an object to see its cost. Objects you can't afford will show up with a red background.\n\nAll unlocked objects are sorted in value order; the least expensive to the most expensive.

Click on a Room from the Empty Rooms and Walls sort within the Rooms and Walls catalog to place it on your lot.\n\nNote: There are many shaped Rooms to start building with, mixing and re-shaping them can create something new and exciting!

You can Remove and Build Walls / Fences by clicking on the wall of a placed Room. Click on a wall to see the available options which vary depending upon the walls current settings. You can also Remove and Build Floors this way.\n\nNote: When a wall has been removed, click on the ghosted wall that appears to get the option to re-build it.

ProTip: Rooms will merge with other Rooms to create a single Room if they share the same exterior walls. This includes Rooms placed inside of other Rooms, such as inner courtyards. This allows you to easily move and manipulate your Rooms, and customize the look you are seeking.
Click to learn more about Fences and Gates.

Select the Place Fences by Drawing or Place Fence Enclosure to begin drawing a fence. When drawing a fence, you can make two types: terrain fence or wall railing.\n\nIf you start drawing on the ground, you'll get a yard fence.

Yard fences are similar to walls, but do not create floors when enclosed, and can't be widened though their length can be adjusted. And their only context menu option is remove them.\n\nNote: You can also delete them with the Sledgehammer Tool.

Fences and Gates can be found in the Build catalog by clicking on their sorts in the House Portrait.\n\nThere are two ways to build fences: by placing them on an existing wall / fence or by drawing them with the Fence Tool.

Select the Replace Fences tool from the Fences catalog. Then select a fence style. Click on an existing wall / fence to replace all wall segments along one side of a Room with the chosen fence.\n\nHold [shift] to replace the entire Room, or [alt] to just replace a single wall segment.

If you start drawing on an existing wall, you'll get a wall railing. Wall railings function exactly as walls.\n\nProTip: You can also create wall railings by choosing Build Fence from a Wall context menu. And then apply a new fence style via the Replace Fence tool.
Click to learn more about Foundations.
Foundations are found in the Build catalog by clicking on the Foundations sort in the House Portrait.

Click on the Go Down to Lower Floor or Go Up to Next Floor buttons to change the floor you are currently viewing. Walls will default to up on any floor below your current floor, and will be hidden for any floor above your current floor.\n\nProTip: You can use [PgUp] and [PgDwn] to toggle between floor levels.

To change the foundation style, choose a style from the catalog and click on the foundation you want to change. The style will apply to all of the foundation for a single Room.\n\nProTip: You can hold shift to only apply the foundation style to one side of a Room.
Build camera controls include an extra option not available in Live Mode, Top Down View. Toggle this option to switch between your normal build camera view and a top down bird's eye view of your lot.

To add foundation to your lot, use the Foundation Height Widget. This can be found in the center of a block when selecting it. 

All blocks that are touching the selected block will raise and lower together. You can raise and lower separate non touching blocks independent from one another. Only Blocks of the same foundation height and on the same build level can be connected together. Blocks on different foundation heights and levels will never be able to connect.

Pro Tip: When trying to match the height of separate block cluster raise and lower the desired cluster until the blocks of the same height and level highlight white.

Click on the Walls View button to toggle between Walls Down, Walls Cutaway, and Walls Up Views.\n\nNote: Walls Cutaway View will hide all walls between your current view and the back wall of your home. As well as cutaway to the active Sim if they happen to be behind the back wall.
Click to learn more about Friezes and Exterior Trims.

Friezes can only be applied to medium or tall walls. The catalog tooltip for a Frieze will indicate the required wall height.\n\nSelect the Frieze sort and choose a style, then click on the Room you want to apply it to. Use the Sledgehammer Tool to remove a Frieze.

Select the Exterior Trims sort and choose a style, then click on the Room you want to apply it to. Use the Sledgehammer Tool to remove an Exterior Trim.\n\nNote: Exterior Trims can not be placed on the first floor.
Friezes and Exterior Trims are found in the Build catalog by clicking on their sort in the House Portrait.

All objects depreciate upon returning to Live Mode. Make sure you have things looking the way you want before you exit Build Mode.\n\nNote: Picking up an object will display its current value in the bottom right corner.

You can place a Pool in two ways: Directly in the terrain or within an existing room. As with Rooms, clicking on the placed Pool will open up a context menu. Use the Move option to pick up and move your Pool. Use the Rotate buttons to rotate the Pool left and right.\n\nProtip: Rotating can be destructive! Pick up your Pool with the Move option and then use the keyboard shortcut [<] and [>] to safely rotate.

Unlike Rooms, there are a few things you are unable to do with Pools. You cannot use manipulator to drag terrain Pools into Rooms or structures on another level--this would be super destructive. You are also unable to remove and build Pools walls via context menu. The water would just flood the space!\n\nProtip: You can drag a Pool into a Room if you first remove the room’s wall.

Click on the Pools sort in the Build catalog to place a Pool on your lot. There is also a Pools Objects sort for additional touches you can add to a Pool.\n\nNote: There are many Pool shapes to start building with. Mixing and re-shaping them can create something new and exciting!

ProTip: Pools will merge with each other to create a single Pool if they share the same exterior walls. This allows you to easily move and manipulate your Pools, and customize the look you are seeking.\n\nNote: Pools and Rooms will not merge since they are different block types.
Click to learn more about Roofs.
Use the arrows to resize width, length and height. Use the knobs to adjust the curve of the roof.
Add extra style to your roofs with patterns and roof trim! Both options are found in the Build catalog by clicking on Roof Patterns and Roof Sculptures sorts.

Selecting a Roof style from the Roofs catalog will change the current floor selection to the first floor that needs a roof. Place the selected Roof on top of a Room, and then use the available adjustments to fine tune it afterwords.
Roofs are found in the Build catalog by clicking on the Roofs sort in the House Portrait.

Click on the Wall Height options that become available once the Rooms and Walls catalog is open. These allow you to adjust the wall height for the current floor.\n\nNote: Some architectural elements, such as friezes, and some doors and windows, require a taller wall.

Default camera style rotates object by clicking the right mouse button when an object is held by your cursor ([ctrl + RMB] will rotate in the opposite direction).

Sims 3 camera style rotates objects by using the left mouse button and dragging to rotate.

ProTip: You can always rotate an object or block held on your cursor by using the [<] or [>] keys.
Click to learn more about Spandrels.
Spandrels are found in the Build catalog by clicking on the Spandrels sort in the House Portrait.

Click on a style in the catalog and then click on the wall you want to apply the Spandrels.\n\nNote: Spandrels can only be placed on a wall and will move anything already placed on the wall to the Household Inventory.

You can remove Spandrels by clicking on the wall and choosing the Remove Spandrels option from the context menu.\n\nNote: Choose the Build Wall or Build Fence option from the context menu to create either after the Spandrels have been removed.
Click to learn more about Stairs and Railings.

Placed stairs can be adjusted much like rooms and walls. Select an existing staircase and use the side arrows to change the width.\n\nYou can also pick up or rotate a placed staircase by selecting the Move and Rotate options from the context menu.
Stairs are found in the Build catalog by clicking on the Stairs sort in the House Portrait.

To create a stairway to a new floor, select a Stair style and bring it towards a Room. The stairway will snap into place when it is close enough. You can click and drag to rotate the stairs to suit your desired placement.\n\nNote: Stairs do not create floors. You will need to attach them to exiting rooms in order to make them useful.

To create a stairway landing, first raise the foundation to the desired height. Select a Stair style from the Stairs catalog, and bring them close to your desired location. They will snap into place.\n\nIf they are not correctly oriented, click and drag to rotate the stairs.
If you want to change the style of an existing staircase, choose a new stair from the catalog and move your mouse on top of the existing stairs and click.
To add a Railing to your stairs, click on the Stair Railings sort in the House Portrait. Choose a railing style from the catalog and click on the staircase you want to add them to.
This is a fast and easy way to instantly create a fully functioning venue!
Click to learn more about Windows.
Windows are found in the Build catalog by clicking on the Windows sort in the House Portrait.
Windows can be placed individually by clicking on the By Window option. Or they can be placed automatically for an entire room by clicking on the By Room option.
Windows can be sorted by height to find the proper window for your wall height. You can also use the Show All sort and find the window height information in the hover tip for each window.
Windows can be moved vertically and horizontally along a wall to get the perfect placement.\n\nProTip: Holding the [alt] key allows for finer vertical placement of windows.
Click to learn more about the Filter Panel.
Build has a powerful filter system that lets you find the exact object you are looking for.\n\nClick the Open Filter Panel arrow at the top of any catalog to view the Filter options.
As filters are turned on, they are added to the list above the catalog. So even when the panel is closed, you'll know what's being filtered.

Turning on Build Mode Filters will find all objects that satisfy any of the Filter choices within the current catalog.\n\nTo remove a filter, click on the [x] for the one you wish to remove, or click the Clear All button to start over.
Filters can also be used to find all of the objects that have been unlocked. Select the Content Filter category, and choose Unlocks.
Click to learn more about the Household Inventory.

Click on the Household Inventory to open the catalog. Use the Function sort pop up and Filters to manage your view within the Household Inventory.\n\nNote: Search will not find objects in the Household Inventory.

Some actions will cause objects to be moved into the Household Inventory. These objects will highlight yellow. Completing the action will move all of the yellow highlighted objects to the Household Inventory.\n\nYou can also place objects into the Household Inventory by picking them up and clicking Place in Inventory.

Similar objects added to the Household Inventory will create a stack. You can see how many a stack contains by the number next to the objects picture. Click on the number to expand the inventory to see the entire stack.

Household Inventory is only available in Build Mode for lots you own. Objects that you don't want to sell, that the game has moved for you, or in some cases that were delivered to you, can all end up in the Household Inventory.\n\nNote: You will get a quick notification when an item is added to the Household Inventory.

Lot Traits are like Sim traits; they give personality to your lot or venue. Most of the traits are great for specific types of Sims and cater to their Skills. They also provide opportunities to tell your own stories.

Lot Traits can be applied to all types of venues. Besides apartments and residences, you can apply traits to commercial venues as well. For example, you can make a Bar with Great Acoustics that is good for performers, since they gain skill faster!
To apply Lot Traits, enter Build Mode and select the Lot Info Panel. You can view traits currently slotted, replace or remove any traits that aren't locked.
Click to learn more about the Wall Tool.
While using the Wall Tool, you can hold the [shift] key to draw a rectangle instead of a single wall. You can also hold the [ctrl] key to destroy any wall it is drawn over.

When drawing walls, you may notice green and yellow highlights.

Green indicates the wall has passed through architecture that will be modified in some way.

Yellow indicates an object that will be moved to the Household Inventory, or sold.

Click on the Rooms and Walls catalog and choose the Empty Rooms sort to find the Wall Tool. Use the Wall Tool to draw individual walls. The cost for placement is attached to the top of the Wall Tool as you drag.\n\nNote: There is also a Room Tool that you can use to draw custom rooms.

Select the Wall Tool and click to begin drawing a wall. Click again to complete the action.

If you draw an enclosed space with the Wall Tool, it will turn into a room with a floor. You can convert a wall into a room by selecting the wall and dragging the side arrows.

Note: Hit [Esc] to cancel any in progress Build action, such as drawing a wall.
Click to learn more about Move Whole House.
Click the Move House tool to move an entire structure to a new location on the lot.
Selecting Move House will set the floor to the maximum floor level in order to see your entire structure.\n\nDe-selecting the tool will return you to your previously selected floor level.
Click on any room or wall to select all connected rooms and walls.\n\nUse the Rotate and Move options in the context menu to reposition your home.

You can also use the Move House tool to quickly sell your home by clicking on the Sell button that appears when you pick it up.\n\nTo end the Move House operation hit [Esc] or select a different tool from the toolbar.
Click to learn more about Navigate Catalog by Function.

Wall and Foundation height can be adjusted from within the Build Catalog.\n\nYou can adjust both of these at any time without worrying about damaging your home, though you may have to clean up your staircases if you remove your foundation.
Once you've built your house, you'll want to furnish it. Click on Objects by Room or Objects by Function to find everything you need to fill out your home.

Click on Objects by Room and select a room style from the options at the top such as Kitchen, Bedroom, or Study. Then click on the Room Portrait to find furnishings appropriate to your chosen room sort.

Choose Objects by Function and use the pop-up menu to view items by function, such as Electronics, Decorations, or Plumbing. Then click one of the sub-sort buttons to further narrow down your options.\n\nUse the Show All sub-sort to view all of the choices within your function category selection.

New home builders might want to start in the Empty Rooms and Walls catalog, where you can find blocks, rooms, and walls to begin building.\n\nThe first two items in this catalog are the Wall and Room Tools. Use these to draw a custom room. Or select any of the other options to place pre-shaped rooms which you can customize to your liking.

The Build Catalog is the home to all of the architectural elements found in Build Mode.

Hover your mouse over the various house parts in the catalog, and click to select the highlighted sort.

ProTip: [F3] is the shortcut for navigating directly to the Build Catalog.

The Flatten to Height tool although similar to the Flatten terrain tool give you more control over the specific heights. Using the Height Slider in the UI you can raise and lower the Height Widget to set the terrain to your desired height. You can also hold the "Ctrl" Key and press the "[ ]" buttons to raise and lower the height widget.

The Raise Terrain tool will raise terrain by clicking and holding your cursor over any empty terrain on the loaded lot. Holding "Ctrl" while clicking will reverse the effects. The "[ ]" keys will change the size of your brush. Use the Speed Slider to determine how fast or slow the terrain will rise.

The Smooth Terrain tool will smooth terrain by clicking and holding your cursor over any empty terrain on the loaded lot. The Smooth Terrain Tool is very helpful for making terrain routable for Sims. To ensure a specific area of terrain is routable make sure you turn on your Topography Lines by clicking "G". Any Terrain that does not have Topography Lines will be routable for your Sims.

The Flatten Terrain tool will adjust terrain to the denoted height of the Height Widget. The Height Widget will snap to the small Topography Lines by default. Holding "Ctrl" will make the height widget snap to the large Topography Lines.

The Flatten Lot button can be found in 2 places. In the terrain Tools UI panel it is the tool that is colored Blue to denote that it is actually a one click button. It can also be found in the Bulldoze drop down at the top of the screen.

The Lower Terrain tool will lower terrain by clicking and holding your cursor over any empty terrain on the loaded lot. Holding "Ctrl" while clicking will reverse the effects. The "[ ]" keys will change the size of your brush. Use the Speed Slider to determine how fast or slow the terrain will lower.
Click to learn more about the Venues button.
From here you can modify various details about your lot such as bedroom and bathroom count, and the lot’s name. You can also view details about the Lot’s current Value and Dimensions.
Click the Lot Info button to open the Lot Info Panel.
You can click the Gallery button next to each lot type to open up “My Library”, pre-filtered to only show lots of that type.
If the lot currently isn’t occupied by any Sims, you can also change the lot’s type by clicking the Lot Type button. This will expand a dropdown list with all the currently available lot types.
Creating a Sim with Genetics is a fun and effective way to build a family. Learn more? NOT USED
When creating a Sim by Playing with Genetics, relationships are automatically applied.\n Note: If you select Sibling as their relationship, you have the option of creating a twin!
Click on the Add a Sim button and choose Playing with Genetics to add a new Sim to your household that uses the other household members as their 'gene pool'.

In the Genetics panel, choose a Relationship (Child, Sibling, or Parent), pick who they are related to, select Gender and Age, and roll your new Sim by clicking the Randomize button.\n If you like the result, click the Checkmark to add the new Sim to your household.
Rotate your Sim to the side to access even more drag options for your Sim!\n Note: Some parts of the body can only be modified from a side view, such as belly size.

If you don't want to start from scratch, click on your Sim's body and choose the Body option from the context menu. The Bodies and Skin Tone catalog includes common and extreme body shapes that you can simply pick and use!\n Note: This will modify your Muscle and Fat settings.
Click and drag on any part of your Sim's body, to create uniquely shaped Sims!
Use the arrows below your Sim to Rotate to set positions.\n Or hold the right mouse button and drag to rotate your Sim with greater precision.
Can't drag the part of your Sim you were hoping to? Rotate your Sims to find and manipulate other points of the face and body.
You can use the mouse wheel to zoom the camera in and out with greater precision.\n Pro Tip: The [+]/[-] keys can also be used to control the camera zoom.
Click on your Sim's Head to zoom in to the face to see more detail. Click away from the face or click on your Sim’s body to zoom out and see the full Sim.
Create a Sim starts you off with a pre-made Sim to mold and transform. Want to see something different? Click Randomize to quickly see what's possible.

Like what you've made? Share your creations to the Gallery!\n Click the Save Household button to save your Sims to your personal Library, or share them to the Gallery for others to download and enjoy!

Once you've found a starting point, you can directly interact with your Sim! Click on what they are wearing to see clothing choices. Click and drag on the body or face to shape them.\nRotate your Sim using the arrows to modify the body from different angles. Pro Tip: The [<]/[>] keys can also rotate your Sim.

Welcome to The Sims 4 Create a Sim!\n This lesson will provide a quick overview of the features available in Create a Sim! To learn more, select any lesson from this Lessons panel. Or, click on the buttons to see what happens.
Select an Aspiration, Traits, Voice, and Walk Style for your Sim! Don't forget to name your Sim!

Expand your household with the Add a Sim button. You can Play with Genetics to add a child, sibling (twins!), or parent.\n Click the Edit Relationships to define relationships between the members of your household.
You can add Sims to this household in Household management. Learn more? NOT USED, IF YOU SEE THIS ITS A BUG
You can't have a household of more than 8 Sims. And only households of young adult or older will be valid for moving into a home.
You can add more than one Sim to your Household by clicking on the Add a Sim button. Choose Add New Sim to add a random Sim to your household.
Face Sculpting is powerful in The Sims 4. Get the most out of the new tools. NOT USED

Once you have finished playing in Detail Edit Mode, click Exit Detail Edit Mode or click on an open spot on the screen to return to Face Mode, where your adjustments remain for overall scaling and position.

Detail Edit Mode exposes a separate layer of adjustments on most parts of your Sim's face.\n Activate Detail Edit Mode by zooming into the face (click on the face) and then clicking on the Detail Edit Mode button or Double Click on any facial feature
There is an important lesson on how the New Face parts work. Check it out? NOT USED

There are unique facial archetypes that you can select to make your Sims look appropriate for different ethnicities. You cannot achieve the look of one shape by manipulating another -- Choose an archetype carefully!\n Tip: Accentuate the presets for dramatic effects!

If you don't want to start from scratch, click on your Sim's face and choose the Face option from the context menu to access the Faces and Skin Tone catalog. Or click on the individual parts of your Sim's face to see their catalog (click on the nose!).\n\nTip: Try various parts from the catalogs to get a shape you want before adjusting it by hand.
Rotate your Sim to the side to access even more drag options for your Sims!\n Note: Some parts of the face can only be modified from a side view, such as nose length!
You can adjust the scale and position for each part of your Sim's face!\n Click and drag on any part of your Sim's face to customize their look to match your imagination!
Filters can be very helpful. Learn More? NOT USED, IF YOU SEE THIS ITS A BUG
As filters are turned on, they are added to the list above the catalog. So even when the panel is closed, you'll know what's being filtered.

Clothing, Accessories and Styled Looks have a powerful filter system that lets you find the exact piece of clothing you're looking for!\n Click the Open Filter Panel arrow at the top of a clothing catalog to view the Filter options.

Pro Tip: Filters can be used to modify Outfit Categories. If you don't want to be limited to Sleepwear for sleeping, turn off the Outfit Category filter, and find exactly what you want with other filter options.

Filters are additive, all items conform to the filters on the list. If nothing shows up in the catalog for your selection (your desire for a Red and Blue, Cotton blend, Designer Basics Sleep outfit may be too specific), try turning off some of your filter options.\n To remove a filter, click on the [x] for the one you wish to remove, or click the Clear All button to start over.

Muscle and Fat adjustments apply to the entire Sim. Muscle controls define shape and size, while Fat controls a layer of 'soft' bulk.\n Click on your Sim's body to access the Muscle and Fat sliders. Click and drag the sliders to adjust them.

Modifications to the body can be added to enhance or hinder the effects of the Muscle and Fat sliders.\n Try dragging the Fat slider all the way to the top, and then drag the parts of your Sim's body to create a unique shape that suits your desires!
Your Sim can have outfits for all occasions. Learn more? NOT USED, IF YOU SEE THIS ITS A BUG

Every Sim has several outfit categories they can customize for themselves: Everyday, Formal, Athletic, Sleepwear, and Party!\n Click on the occasion icons at the top of any clothing catalog to begin customizing that outfit!
To change the clothes in an outfit, select that outfit category and start trying new clothes on! What the Sim is wearing is the current outfit.
Each category sets a preset filter of clothing options to choose from. This filter is only a suggestion of appropriate items per occasion. Feel free to change or remove the filters as you wish!

Maybe you noticed the Outfit Slots that appear when you select an Outfit Category? Every category can have up to 5 slots! Just click the [+] button to add a new Outfit Slot and begin customizing a host of outfits for your Sim!\n Note: You can delete the slots by clicking the [x] button that appears on hover, but you can't delete the currently selected Outfit!

Who is your Sim?\n Click on the Personality button to begin answering just who your Sim is. You can choose your Sim's Age, Gender, Walk Style, Voice, and if you have more then one Sim in your household, their Relationships to one another.

Click on the Pick an Aspiration button to make your selection. Most Aspiration categories have multiple options. For instance, click on Food and choose between Master Chef and Master Mixologist!\n Once you select an Aspiration, your Sim receives a Bonus Trait that you can see next to your selected Aspiration.

"Hello, My Name Is…"\n Name your Sim! Who are they? Click on the text to expand the Name Panel, and type in First and Last names for the Sim. No idea what to name your Sim? Click Randomize Name and let us pick one for you!
Your Sim's first Aspiration! What does your Sim aspire to? Will they be a Bestselling Author, Serial Romantic, Fabulously Wealthy, or the Chief of Mischief?

Traits are an important part of defining your Sim's Personality. Click on the Pick a Trait buttons to select up to 3 Traits from the categories available.\n Some Traits can't be paired with other Traits. You can't be both Good and Evil. And there are no negative Traits. They all provide unique opportunities for your Sims.

Randomize your Sim to find a good starting point for their appearance.\n See something you like? But maybe the face isn't quite right, or the clothing choice isn't what you are looking for? Open up the Randomize pop out and select the specific parts you want to randomize.
Random is also available from within many of the detail pop outs (clothing, face details, hair style, …). Use this random option to randomize the specific catalog sort you are browsing.
You can add and edit relationships in this household. Learn More? NOT USED, IF YOU SEE THIS ITS A BUG

Once you have more than 1 Sim in your household, you can set your Sims' relationships to one another. Who's whose parent? Is he a brother, a roommate, or a father?\n Click on the Personality button and choose Edit Relationships.

In the Edit Relationships panel, you can set the relationships for each household member to the current Sim.\n Click on the drop down next to the Sim portrait to choose their relationship to that Sim.
When you are done making edits, click the Checkmark to close the panel.

Setting one relationship can have an effect on other relationships. If a choice you made causes a previous relationship setting to become invalid, an alert will appear next to the relationship of the modified Sim.

There are multiple selections in each category. Click the arrows at the bottom to swap between the different looks!\n There are also several color options. Click on the different color swatches to browse the colors.
Click on the Styled Looks to begin browsing the preset outfits we've put together for you! Use them as they are, or treat them like a starting point to create your own outfits.

There are looks for every occasion. You can change the Outfit Category at the top and try on anything, click the Try this Style button to put on the outfit.\n Note: Hair, Face, and Body shape won't change by applying any of the Styled Looks.
Sleek boards and nimble fingers. Come for the chess but be prepared to stay for the night.
A hexagonal fluted column with a wide cap.
A round column with a square cap reminiscent of ancient architecture but without the frills.
Square column, round cap, Italian inspiration.
This column stands tall, free of extraneous adornment, its simple round shape enough to enliven the eye.

Are you prepared to start collecting columns with the big boys? Ready to take that next step? You will NEVER find another column that is both as straight and as round as this one. We know because we asked robots to design it. The Deluxe Mega Column: because you are seriously not messing around anymore.

We were admiring the use of straight lines in mission-style design, and someone said “Hey, you know what’s really straight? Columns!” So we designed a series of columns. Here’s the Budget DeLite version for beginning column collectors.

Just because you decorate your house in a simple arts and crafts style doesn’t mean you can’t add a little class to the place. A few marble columns will make people say “Whoa. Where’d all this class come from?” You gotta get yourself some marble columns!
Square geometric patterns help to add interest to an otherwise rather plain architectural column.
A solid square column enhanced by sharp corners and severe lines.
There's no such thing as excess when it comes to outfitting your architectural column.
A column designed to imply classical influences without actually committing to them.
An architectural column reminiscent of antique staircase spindles.
Accept, and Select Sims to Travel with
Are you ready to start?\n\nThis will end any currently running events.
Hi {0.SimFirstName}, it's your job agency calling... Just a friendly reminder that there are plenty of gigs available to work on if you're interested in earning some money. No pressure!
This workout ensemble goes the distance in performance and style! So breathable, comfy, and cute, you can feel the wind all over.
You've got the strength to smoke the competition, so why hide it? This high-performance tank and short set is cut skintight to eliminate drag and keep you light and powerful.
Nothing makes you look racier than this curve-hugging track set. Constructed of feather-light, moisture-wicking fabric, with a splash of color to highlight your head-snapping silhouette.
We’re mad for this rockin’ plaid mini skirt and skull tee combo. Actually, we’re just mad. If you’re a chick that gets angry a lot, this is a good look. Rock it.
Get swept away by this romantic floral-print dress and sunhat ensemble that adds flirty, feminine flair to any season, as long as you’re not f-f-freezing.
Bare just enough shoulder to raise curiosity about your undergarments. Bare just enough leg to seem like you’re wearing only undergarments.
Embellished with feminine details, this dashing tweed jacket and short set creates a fabulously unforgettable, oops-I-should-have-dry-cleaned-this effect.
Wild West meets Hard Rock in this tough-as-tulips look that’ll lasso everyone’s attention. From your cowgirl hat to your high-top sneakers, this star-studded ensemble says “howdy” to flirtatious fun.
Draw attention to your lovely lines with this elegantly paneled formal dress! An elegant choker and ankle-strap heels create the perfect frame for your masterful new look.
Mirror, mirror, on the wall: Who’s the most fabulous of them all? Why, you, of course, in this elegant floor-length number with matching satin gloves and a shimmering brooch.
Soar to new heights of fashion with this futuristic outfit. Bold colors, a stellar neckline, and reflective belt will make you the life of the party throughout the universe, and beyond.
Biker chic meets floral fancy in this alluring combination that lets the world know that you're no wallflower.
Show off your wild side in this ferocious wrap top and cheetah-print mini. Hunt or be hunted, but beware one thing: you won’t escape notice long. Meow.
Fetch all the attention in this playful combination of a simple little mini with studded bracelet and spike collar. Everyone will beg to get your number!
Dream of the days when you were just a tender girl-child, be-ribboned in bows and delicate flowers. Now dress as if nothing’s changed. Includes ballerina slippers!
Snuggle up in something soft, cute, and cuddly—just like you! Somebunny Special robes and slippers are made from the plushest velour, so you feel just like a real rabbit.
Nothing’s dreamier than this baby-tee and boxer short combo for the ultimate in comfort and carefree style.
Bring your A-game on and off the court with action-ready basketball gear featuring ultra-ventilated elite-length shorts and stripes so dizzying, all anyone’ll remember is the sting of defeat.
Who wears short shorts? Why, you do! The Retro Runner set gets you moving in 70s style.
Athletic comfort never goes out of style with 24 Hour Fitwear! This relaxed-fitting tracksuit is the ultimate in flexible.
Keep a cool profile with casually cuffed jeans, a closefitting tee and a denim jacket with hoodie built in.
Square glasses frame your sensitive eyes, a tight tee reveals the weight of the world on your shoulders, and pants boast two zippers to contain your emotions.
The modern male must always be prepared-whether the day serves up a round of golf, fog, or a Ridgeport.
Under that cap and stylish scarf is a guy who fears nothing--not judgment, not public opinion, maybe just socks.
This beautifully tailored suit is all business, though it plays handsomely at special occasions as well.
Going to a gala? Our Black Tie-in-a-Box will have you pretty as a penguin in no time!
Step your look up a notch with this fresh-as-rain designer ensemble featuring a notch-collar jacket, v-neck tee and pressed bootcut pants.
Parties can be tricky affairs-sometimes fancy, sometimes casual, sometimes canceled-which is why we created the perfect ensemble for any party that actually exists.
Life’s a beach, so why not dress the part? This relaxed ensemble is as supremely comfortable as it looks.
How do you dress nice without looking like you’re going to funeral? Behold: the skinny tie.
Embrace your softer side. Somebunny Loves You Loungewear for Men is made from the plushest velour, so you feel snuggly and frisky as a rabbit.
Sleep like a real man in this athletic tank and flannel pant set. Designed to show off your powerful pectorals and to only kind-of, sort-of match.
Market research showed the word Atomic tested well. So… The ATOMIC Fence!! Um, it's a fence.
With smooth lines and elegant curves, this fence will make your Lot look like a text book example of minimalistic elegant style. Place it to make your Lot exude effortless elegance.
Turned wood fenceposts support slender composite slats, resulting in a handsome and versatile fencing option.
Carved wood posts alternate with wooden slats reinforced by metal bars.
Geometric designs in metal add eye appeal to this sturdy fencing rendered in the Prairie style.
Carved stone and concrete lend an air of implacability to this privacy wall.
A picket fence more decorative than functional.
Nothing fancy, just a picket fence.
A picket fence with wide columns and wide slats.
This fence with narrow pickets has a delicate, unimposing air.
Turned wood balusters plus square posts equals a pleasing contrast for the eye to behold.
Large slabs of stone define a very Modernist wall.
Edge your property line and defend your privacy with a dense row of shrubbery.
Edge your property line and defend your privacy with a flowery row of shrubbery.
Curves and whorls soften the look of this wrought iron fencing, rendering it suitable for all your Mediterranean-inspired architectural needs.
Wrought iron fencing is a must for everything from Spanish Revival courtyards to haunted Gothic mansions.
Cut stone is arranged to form a low wall of mostly symbolic value.
There is no better visual tool to separate the haves from the have-nots than this plush velvet rope. A must for all nightclubs, movie premieres and banks.
The stark blankness of the large fencing panels is softened by the rounded curves of hardwood fence posts.

Due to a catastrophic error in the logic of our fence-crafting robot AI, our assembly line of robots suddenly forgot how to make straight lines and produced these intricate fences. While not strictly mission-style, they are pretty nice looking. We decided to call this our “Deluxe” model.
At first glance, it might strike you how much the Budget DeLite model of our Mega Fence resembles a plain slab of concrete.
In honor of the simple beauty of mission style, we wanted to offer as many straight lines on our basic fence as possible. We stopped at 76, though. More than that would just be decadent.
Ladder-like fencing with a rustic, unfinished look.
Reminiscent of barnyard enclosures, this horizontal fencing is particularly well-suited for children to climb on.
Combine privacy and natural splendor in one package with this green privacy hedge. Provides ample habitat for stray wildlife, too.
Say it with flowers -- in this case, "privacy please" is the message you're sending, thanks to a tall, dense living hedge.
No fuss, no nonsense, no frivolous details, just a series of wood-framed panels to screen your private property from prying eyes.
Tile detailing sets this privacy wall apart from imitators. Use to screen off your sun-soaked garden patio.
Rough-hewn slabs of sandstone provide little ambiance but plenty of privacy.
A precise balance of earthy wood and crisp geometry makes for a stately set of fencing.
Do not be fooled by its unassuming look. This fence means business, it is a pretty good fence. It does the job.
A privacy screen with extra visual interest thanks to interwoven lattice panels that provide a peek beyond the fence line.
One's home is one's castle, and a castle needs fortifications. This hulking stone privacy fence is up to the job. Good for cemeteries and Gothic mansions, too.
Classy yet no-nonsense, expensive but practical, a muscular fence such as this makes a clear visual statement when surrounding your estate.
No embellishments are needed for this simple picket fence laden with symbolic virtue.
Wooden slats are framed by tall, ball-topped posts for an elegant take on the classic picket fence.
Tall posts with geometric caps alternate with timeless wooden pickets for a fencing solution both handsome and sturdy.
Where the Rubber Hits the Road
Hold down the Shift key and click to apply flooring to an entire room. While selecting a floor pattern, press Ctrl and F to apply a quarter of a tile.
Out to Pasture Grass with Wildflowers
Water that doesn't look like water? If not water, what is it?
Walk the Short Plank Hardwood Floors
This molding adds a bit of interest at each story of your home.
Like a drainpipe without the drain! For the brutalists out there.
Smooth and clean. For those that love the details!
Earthquakes, hurricanes, pestilence, floods-nothing can take down the AF.
With all the charm of old-fashioned bricks, but twice the crack resistance.
Poured fresh for you in less than 3 hours. Not holding up? We’ll pour it again.
Solid as a ton of bricks and hefty with charm, this foundation will stand strong, at least until there’s a problem.
Exposed bricks are back in! Go for that industrial look… where you see it, and where you don’t.
Exposed bricks are back in! Go for that industrial look… where you see it, and where you don’t.
From country cottages to falling-down farmhouses, add charm to your exterior with lattice work you’ll love.
Want your house in mid-air? This style will keep you one step above the rest.
Whatever the weather, you need a foundation you can trust. This is it.
Beautifully pocked like the stars in the sky, this reinforced foundation won’t ever let you down.
Some say wood will never last, but this firm fellow defies the odds, supporting happy homes since 1912.
Make a statement heard around the neighborhood with custom argyle masonry surrounding your home.
Functional is cool, but fashionable is much better.
Why even to try to fit in? Give suburbanites something to talk about from the moment you start to build.
Square vs. Round... Really, why are we even discussing this, the only acceptable answer is square.
Round vs. Square... the answer should obviously be unanimous for round.
There's nothing like a bit of tile to give a water feature some retro class.
Classical fountains the world over have been carved from stone like this. Jump on the bandwagon.
Let the water speak for itself.

The camp's counselors are distressed that {0.SimFirstName} did not complete all of the assigned goals. Who will properly teach the youth now?! It got even worse for them when they read the fine print of the contract, and discovered they still owned {0.SimFirstName} partial pay for the portion of the work {M0.he}{F0.she} completed.

{0.SimFirstName}'s heart swelled with joy at the opportunity to pass down {M0.his}{F0.her} artistic skills to the next generation of talented painters. The children's eyes were wide with wonder as {M0.he}{F0.she} gave {M0.his}{F0.her} demonstration, and they leapt to action in an attempt to recreate {M0.his}{F0.her} painting. The counselors expressed their gratitude by letting {0.SimFirstName} sign the wall of one of the camp's cabins, as well as slipping {M0.him}{F0.her} a bonus payment.

{0.SimFirstName} took pride in teaching the camp's self-proclaimed "artists of tomorrow". While {M0.he}{F0.she} isn't 100% certain they'll all live up to that lofty aspiration, {M0.he}{F0.she} knows {M0.he}{F0.she} did her part to usher them down the right path.

Having not completed all of {M0.his}{F0.her} expected goals, the art students went untaught for the day, and are angrily lodging complaints to the dean's office. Per the substitute professor contract, {0.SimFirstName} still managed to walk away with a portion of {M0.his}{F0.her} pay.

{0.SimFirstName} will never admit it, but {M0.he}{F0.she} greatly enjoyed booting an unruly student out of class. Everyone else was remarkably well behaved though; one student even gave {M0.him}{F0.her} an apple to show their gratitude! Word of {0.SimFirstName}'s great job reached the dean, who paid {M0.him}{F0.her} a little bonus for a job well done.
